utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) politician like Trudeau and others in the past can always punch that button and know they will get a response from some in the Canadian electorate who just don't like the Americans.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes, most of them are localized around the Quebec or the French- speaking areas, I think, right?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Professor, always good seeing you, my friend. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: WEAD
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Doug Wead, a good read on things. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } That is true. Depending on the region, they either love or hate us. But, well, in this particular fight, the foreign press has not been kind to one Donald Trump. And all of this ahead a bigger meeting that the president is having, in fact, the reason why he is leaving early, that one in Singapore. That's the one that's getting all the world's attention -- after this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, I don't know if this is exactly worthy of a FOX News Alert, but a FOX News poll that really isn't too jolting, but it could be a sort of a wind at the president's back, showing two out of three of Americans support this summit he is going to be having with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un. Now, the U.S. and North Korea, if they actually come away from this with something, even if it doesn't appear to be eye-popping progress, but something, then it could change everything. Now, of course, what would something be? The author of "The Operator," former Navy SEAL Rob O'Neill, with me. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } Rob, good to have you.

utterances.speaker: ROB O'NEILL, FORMER U.S. NAVY SEAL
utterances.sentences: Thanks for having me, Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: One ever the common phrases we hear, Rob, is denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. Both sides agree that's an integral issue. We have very big differences on the timetable. We want it fast, the North Koreans, not so fast.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: Well, there are so many arguments with that, because a lot of people are saying that Kim Jong-un is sort of playing along, knowing that President Trump could be out in a few years, seven years at the most. And then he could play the next administration, which his grandfather, Kim Il- Sung, and then Kim Jong Il and then Kim Jong-un...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: How likely do you think that is? It has happened twice before.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: I don't think it is. I just think, with a lot of the technology coming up, that Kim Jong-un wants to maintain power. And the way he maintains power is without an invasion of his country. He really wants to avoid an invasion. That was one of the things that he was saying in the demilitarized zone and then in South Korea, that if we can guarantee the U.S. will not invade, which we really don't have interest in doing, he gets to sort of maintain power. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } And that's a whole different ball of wax once they get the technology in there. But if he realizes -- he gets to keep power with nukes. He knows that is a deterrent. But if he can get rid of them, hopefully releasing some of the -- some of the pressure of the economic sanctions, he gets more stuff in there, his people, not that he really cares about his people, but, if they get fed, that, again, will come with him maintaining power. Just to get a face-to-face with the leader of the free world, which no one in North Korea ever has, that's a step in the right direction. And he can hear face to face, along with an invite to Mar-a-Lago or to the White House. He wants to be legitimized. He wants to keep his power. This is definitely a step in the right direction. Even if nothing comes out of it, they have already started negotiating. Once, they called it off, called it -- put it back on. And then President Trump is going to leave the G7 summit tomorrow early to get to Singapore to start. This is a great first step in foreign policy.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, now, you never like being called a hero, but I think, if you take down Usama bin Laden, you are categorized as that in my book. But, having said that, how would feel if we do normalize relations and down the road there is Kim Jong-un at the White House with the president of the United States?

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: It's a tough one. I mean, President Trump has invited Vladimir Putin, too. And a lot of people on the left are saying, you know, you bring -- you know, he is a guy that has tortured his own people. He's not a good guy. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But we can't pick and choose the leaders of the countries we must negotiate with.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: Look at some of the people that call themselves our allies. I would rather be stabbed in the front than stabbed in the back. That's kind of what it is. And maybe he comes around. Look at Pakistan, OK? We give them millions and millions, hundreds of millions in aid. And they hid bin Laden on us. They are hiding the Haqqani Network. How do you start? What, do we just ignore them?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But, viscerally, you could deal with that? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } Much the same FDR couldn't pick and choose the leader of Russia when he was talking to Stalin. And here he was.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: Well, and they were calling him Uncle Joe at the time. He turned out not to be a great guy. He killed millions of people.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. So, leaving that out of the argument here, the sense seems to be, the North Korean needs something out of this a lot more than we do.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: So, what do we offer in exchange that doesn't look like we are caving? And that was the rap against Bill Clinton. That was the rap, fairly or not, against President....

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, we are offering relief. We're offering -- he likes his money. He wants to be seen as a world leader. He loves prestige. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } But it seems to me, even I said he was crazy before on television. He might not be as crazy as we thought. But, you know, he wants to be legitimized. And he wants -- hopefully, they see what kind of -- look at the wealth in Seoul, South Korea, compared to Pyongyang. And they got a lot of that because of capitalism and because of cooperating with the world. There is a lot of good stuff. And right now, they are trading mainly with China and some with Singapore, which is why -- one of the many reasons why the summit is going to be in Singapore. But if they can trade with more people and they don't -- they're not necessarily under the thumb of the Chinese, that could be in their interest. We will see. You have got to figure, since the early '50s, the people have been being lied to, being told this family are gods, and it's going to take a lot to bring them around.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But can you unify the two?

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: Hopefully.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: The father envisioned there would be no North or South Korea, there would be one Korea, and the North would be running it.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: There should be. They tried it through communism. But he probably didn't imagine his grandson would be holding hands and skipping across the demilitarized zone with the leader of South Korea. I mean, it's very interesting, to say the least. And it's -- I'm looking forward to it.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes. All right. It is going to be pay-per-view watching.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: Oh, certainly.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Thank you very, very much, Rob O'Neill, former U.S. Navy SEAL, the man who brought down Usama bin Laden.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, $100 trillion, by the way, that's how much Americans are worth right now. And it's never been that big. It's never been that high. So, how optimistic are you? Why that number could change a big number in November -- after this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You feeling a little richer these days? Well, you are part of the $100 trillion richer. That's America's total household worth. Now, of course, a lot of it has been buoyed by the markets and higher home evaluations. And, of course, this week got a little bit more so with all the major market averages up appreciably, even with some of the concerns that have been out there. So, what's the heck is going out there? Let's get the read from Gary B. Smith and Melissa Armo. Melissa, this just seems weird at face value, that the markets would climb with all these worries. Then I see $100 trillion worth figure, and I go, maybe it's just people feeling more robust and bullish that is driving it.

utterances.speaker: MELISSA ARMO, THE STOCK SWOOSH
utterances.sentences: I think the market is getting used to Trump. But I think it's really surprising that we are rallying into this meeting with North Korea. This is a big week coming up next week. We are right at a critical level for the S&P and the Dow. If we get over 26000 in the Dow, we are going to make new highs. And I never thought that would happen this summer. Let me just say, if we make new highs in the next few months this summer, that is so early and unexpected to me for the way the price action looked back in February, when we fell. We will explode right up into the next presidential election for Trump to get going and maybe reelected again. He might actually get reelected again if the market runs up like that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, Mitt Romney, I think, earlier said that. But, you know, Gary B., I'm wondering, all these years I have known you and talked to you, you know, you have talked about meltdowns and melt-ups. And a lot of people look at what's been happening of late, and does this have a melt-up feeling to it? We keep climbing up, up, up, up?

utterances.speaker: GARY B. SMITH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: What did Warren Buffett say? He thought we were in the sixth inning?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: ... a baseball game is nine innings. We're two-third through it.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: That about feels right. Right now...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: So, this longest bull market about in history is going to get longer still by a third?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I think so. And here's why. You know, the expression politics is local? I think the economy is also local to people's pocketbooks. We have low unemployment. We have -- you just talked about the household net worth. We have housing prices, at least per the Case-Shiller index, has eclipsed the highs back in 2006. People have jobs. Wages are climbing.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, fortunately, no one is underwater like they used to be, right?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Exactly. There might be...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Not like a national...

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Right. Right. Exactly. In general, people aren't being foreclosed on. Everything's working right now. Could there be a black swan out there? Of course. Always. But, right now, I'm with Buffett. I think we have a ways to run right now. And, you know, a lot of these tax cuts haven't even kicked in yet.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Buffett also mentioned we haven't even gotten to our heavy hitters yet. What was he referring to when he said that we are two-thirds through something or that bigger things could come that could propel this still higher? What do you look at?

utterances.speaker: ARMO
utterances.sentences: Well, meaning, just like Gary just said, corporations haven't even filed. Neither have individuals filed for 2018, when we have the tax cuts. Now, people if they got paid in their W-2s, they are seeing the savings. But companies, maybe if they reported quarterly earnings, pay in ahead. But no one has filed or required to file until April of 2019 for the big tax cuts.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But individuals in high-tax states, like the one you are in right now, they will -- they might be surprised that they are not getting as much as they wanted, because their deductions are limited. Right?

utterances.speaker: ARMO
utterances.sentences: Right. Well, we will see.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ARMO
utterances.sentences: Obviously, we will have to see. Obviously, we have the elections coming up in a couple of months. That's going to affect it. But, overall, people do vote their wallets. If things are good, if people are at work, if they are looking at their 401(k)s and the market continues to rally, and they are blowing up, blowing up, their 401(k) is getting bigger, people feel safer. They feel like, I can go out and I can put money or spending something on a credit card and things are going to be OK. Instead of when people voted Trump in, they wanted change so badly, they didn't care at any cost. They didn't care that Trump never was in government before. People when it comes up are going to say, hey, we don't want things to change. Things are kind of going maybe pretty good now. We don't want any change.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: And a trade war, the prospect of that doesn't rattle you?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: No. I don't think so. Look, I don't like what he is doing with trade.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I would like no barriers. I would like, you want to dump your goods...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Something is working.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: You want to dump your goods in here and we just give you bills with old presidents on them, I'm happy with that. But that's not going to happen. I think Trump -- we talked about it just before we went on -- he has a way of landing on his feet. Is this some, you know, amazing genius negotiating strategy? Who knows? But it tends to work out for the guy. I'm going to start giving him the benefit of the doubt.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: And he did bring to people's attention, even those who didn't know, that there are a lot of countries that rig the game.

utterances.speaker: ARMO
utterances.sentences: It wasn't fair. See, he had to take a hard stance. If he didn't take a hard stance...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But with Canada? I mean, it's making syrup.

utterances.speaker: ARMO
utterances.sentences: He's taken a hard stance. And we are going to see what's going to happen. They need us just as much as we need them. And that's the truth.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: The other thing is, I think he understands one thing. He understands that, in the G7, in NAFTA, we're the big dog. And he has shown the ability the one thing the past presidents have not done. He is willing to say, this isn't working, I'm walking away. Oh, boy, it's like going in the car dealer and saying, you know what? The price isn't right. I'm leaving. They come running after you, please, buy the car.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: I have done that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: And the say, we don't want you to be our customer. All right.

utterances.speaker: ARMO
utterances.sentences: I live in New York. I don't need a car.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes. Rub it in. Rub it in. All right, guys, we will see what happens.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But, to their point, if the markets are rattled by all these nerve-racking developments or what would normally be considered nerve- racking, they have a funny way of showing it. A lot more on that after this. In the meantime, there is new video of James Wolfe leaving court. Now, he's the former Senate staffer indicted by the Department of Justice over these alleged leaks. And, man, oh, man, those leaks and who he was leaking to and then the I.G. report next week, you can't make this stuff up. Well, even though a lot of people make stuff up -- after this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, this is pre-disinviting somebody. The president saying, no matter who wins the NBA finals, well, they are not getting an invite to the White House. Is that his call to make or is he making a point that others can't take? After this.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It's very interesting that they caught a leaker and a very important -- and it's a very important leaker. So it's very interesting. I'm getting information on it now. Happened last night. It could be a terrific thing. I know -- I believe strongly in freedom of the press. I'm a big, big believer in freedom of the press. But I'm also a believer in classified information.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, the president talks about James Wolfe. That's a former Senate staffer indicted by the Department of Justice for lying to the FBI over intel leaks. And now we don't know who got those leaks and how many people shared those leaks. It's a soap opera here. Attorney Troy Slaten on all these developments. Troy, this is yet the latest wrinkle and will feed a narrative the president has long had that it's a rigged system and a rigged system going for him. What do you make of it?

utterances.speaker: TROY SLATEN, ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: And it's also going to feed into arguments that there is a deep state of career people working in the government that are seeking to forward their own agenda. This is really unsettling, because this is not just any Senate staffer. This is the guy that was director of security for the Senate Intelligence Committee. This is a big deal. The Senate Intelligence Committee has some of the highest level of secrets in our government. That's why they have those rooms that -- where the glass goes opaque at the switch of a button, where they have their own servers. This is a really big deal, Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: I like those offices where the glass goes opaque. I just think that is so cool. But, leaving that aside, I'm wondering, how it is they, A, discovered the leaks, and then we keep hearing of them. I mean, it's a sieve there, and it's out of control.

utterances.speaker: SLATEN
utterances.sentences: Well, he had a personal relationship with a reporter who was working at the time for BuzzFeed.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SLATEN
utterances.sentences: And they subpoenaed -- well, they didn't subpoena. They went and used national security letters and got copies of her e-mails from Google and the other service providers. They eventually let her employer know that they had retrieved all her information. And then they interviewed him and asked him, did you ever divulge any information? He lied and said no. And that's the problem. The cover-up is usually worse than the crime. This is the way they got Martha Stewart, Rod Blagojevich, and many others, Jeffrey Skilling at Enron. This is a big deal.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You know, next week, we're also going to get the I.G. report on Comey and the Justice Department, on Barack Obama and Loretta Lynch, and the clumsy handling of that investigation and who knew what and when and shared what and when. Where is this going to land us a week from now?

utterances.speaker: SLATEN
utterances.sentences: Well, who knows? And we're waiting all with bated breath to see the I.G. report that the top brass at the Department of Justice has already had and is reviewing and is probably trying to make redactions, they will say, for national security reasons. There -- others will say that it's to do it to kind of protect their own butt and CYA. But who knows? The reports are so far that that I.G. report is going to be scathing for not only Comey, but former Director McCabe.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes. All right. It's pretty clear that the president's former campaign manager is under the very watchful and increasingly more aggressive eyes of Bob Mueller, with a new indictment and talk among some in the Mueller staff that he even wanted to throw him in jail while we wait all of this out. Where do you see this going? And do you agree with those who say, whatever it happening in the circle of people who used to be associated with then candidate Trump, that this still means that there is no target in one Donald Trump?

utterances.speaker: SLATEN
utterances.sentences: Well, it's hard to say where the special counsel is going. With regard to Manafort, he has only been charged with financial crimes that really had nothing to do with his time as campaign manager or anything having to do with the Trump campaign or the election from 2016. And as far as them wanting to throw him in jail, that has to do with allegations from prosecutors that he was engaged in witness tampering while he has been out on pre-trial release, therefore, violating the terms of his bond, his own-recognizance release.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, thank you very, very much. We will see how this all goes and sorts out. But it could go a variety of ways, Troy. Thank you very, very much.

utterances.speaker: SLATEN
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, I want to give you the numbers on pardons. Five, five for one president, 63 for another president. Those are pardons under a president at this stage of his presidency. You probably think that the 63 refer to Donald Trump. You're wrong. They are Ronald Reagan at this point. The five, for all the hullabaloo about pardons, that's all Donald Trump has had. More after this.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We have 3,000 names. We're looking at them. Of the 3,000 names, many of those names really have been treated unfairly.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You know, for all the controversy surrounding the president and his pardons, he has not really pardoned that many people. This, of course, the latest one being the sentence relief that he provided for Alice Marie Johnson this week. She was serving a life sentence over a nonviolent drug charge. And she thanked the president profusely. But are we looking at this the correct way here? Let's get the read from attorney Whitney Boan. Whitney, I was surprised to see, as we look at this point in respective presidencies, that the president is actually pretty low on the totem pole when it comes to pardons. He has had five. But some presidents have had far more, like Bush Sr. at this point in his presidency or Ronald Reagan before that or Jimmy Carter or even Gerald Ford.

utterances.speaker: WHITNEY BOAN, ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Now, I know some his recent compatriots, not so much. But they did make up for lost time in total of pardons as their presidencies ensued. So, why does this president get the attention he does?

utterances.speaker: BOAN
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that there's two separate issues here. First is whether or not he is abusing the power in terms the number of pardons he is issuing or if he is commuting sentences in a disproportionate manner. That's a separate issue than whether or not people disagree with the substance of maybe why he is pardoning people or the people who he is choosing to pardon in terms of -- obviously, there has been a lot of controversy -- less so about Alice Johnson -- but about the sheriff from Arizona, in terms of his...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOAN
utterances.sentences: ... his flouting in the face of the judicial system and disregarding a court order. So, I don't think it's odd in terms of the number.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, I could say that also, though, about Marc Rich. You remember that famous pardon with Bill Clinton and all. So, you are right. I mean, depending on the time and place, they can raise eyebrows. Normally, a lot of this is bunched up, oftentimes, not all the time, near the end of a presidency than the beginning.

utterances.speaker: BOAN
utterances.sentences: Right. Correct.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But the president has already indicated this unique power that he has, he would like to address thousands of potential cases, even included Muhammad Ali. But, of course, his family and the legal associates reminded him that the Supreme Court itself exonerated him. But what do you make of that?

utterances.speaker: BOAN
utterances.sentences: Right. Well, what I make of it is this. We are in a day and time where everything our president does is being scrutinized. Prior presidents since Bill Clinton, basically since his administration, and then through G.W.'s and Obama's, they have slowed their pace in terms that they wait, like you said, until later in the presidency to start making these pardons, because they are kind of comfortably within their term. We are only 504 days in here. And so you combine those factors and, yes, it seems like maybe this is a lot, but it's really not. It's more concerning, like you said, though, if he is talking about pardoning thousands of people. I don't have any issue with it, as a criminal defense attorney, because I actually have some names. And, President Trump, if you are watching, you can call me, and I will give you some more to add to that list of clients of mine who I would like to see receive presidential pardons. But -- and then, certainly, there's a lot of people that have been treated unfairly. I just think it's scary to people, and maybe rightfully so. And maybe we just pay attention to the fact that he has this newfound power, and he is like a kid in a candy shop. And we don't want it to be that we are just throwing around pardons because we can. We want it to have meaning. We want it to have significance. And we want it to be fair.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: In this latest case of this woman who was in jail for so long on a drug charge, do you think that was a justifiable release, commutation, I guess?

utterances.speaker: BOAN
utterances.sentences: Absolutely, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOAN
utterances.sentences: But where I am with it is, if we are going to have thousands of people pardoned -- and her sentence was commuted. She wasn't given a full pardon.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: BOAN
utterances.sentences: The difference is, her sentence was mitigated and it was shortened. She is not not a convicted felon at this point. She is still a convicted felon. A pardon is a whole other thing. You don't even have to be convicted of a crime to receive a pardon. A pardon basically gives you immunity from any further punishment as a result of a presidential pardon.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: That's the result of that. All right.

utterances.speaker: BOAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. I would love to see people like Alice Johnson or people in her position receive pardons or commutations of their sentence. But if it's going to be other things, again, we will see how it plays out. But it's concerning.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right. Yes. We have started something here. Whitney Boan, have a great weekend. Thank you very, very much.

utterances.speaker: BOAN
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Neil. You too.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, remember when everyone was jumping ugly with the president over tweeting so many nasty things? Well, now the people who are upset at him are tweeting some very nasty things -- after this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, one of the most popular segments on modern television.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Kind of. All right. I don't know if you saw this a little earlier. All smiles for the big photo-ops. You would never assume there are any problems. But I got to tell you, at this G7 summit, the odd man out is the president of the United States. Now, that seems to be the way he likes it. Let's get read from young and funky kids. And we begin with Dion Baia, FOX News correspondent Lea Gabrielle. I don't know why she said yes, but so happy she did.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: We have also got Kat Timpf back with us, and Internet radio sensation and my friend Mike Gunzelman. They call him Gunz. Dion, what do you make of this?

utterances.speaker: DION BAIA, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: I don't know. He is getting into odd territory where he's tweeting about our allies. And then it's like openly airing our laundry -- or his dirty laundry about what's going on. And...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But maybe that's a good thing. What do you guys think? It's a good thing?

utterances.speaker: MIKE GUNZELMAN, INTERNET RADIO HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, I think it's Trump being Trump. And we have come to expect this by now. And the only reason they are mad at us is because his policies and everything, the tariffs are helping us, and they are affecting their -- you know, Macron in Canada and Germany, their economies. So I don't care as long as our president is looking out for ourselves.

utterances.speaker: KATHERINE TIMPF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: And no one should be surprised by this, because although Donald Trump has been kind of all over the place on a lot of issues, he has been very consistent on tariffs. We shouldn't be surprised to see that has been doing this. And it doesn't really matter what I think. It doesn't matter what Macron thinks. It doesn't matter Justin Trudeau thinks. He is not going to change his mind.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But you do this with your friends?

utterances.speaker: LEA GABRIELLE, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think that this is a president who promised to bring his business style to the White House. And I think this is where he is most comfortable. I think he likes to do this. The only problem here is that, in sort of the free market, you can always walk away from a deal, because you can just find another company to do the deal with. But you can't just say, oh, well, I'm just going to find another Canada to deal with right now. So, I think that that is the challenge here, is that this is a different kind of deal that he is doing with countries, rather than with companies. But I think that that's just the way he likes to run things.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: I wonder if we spread ourselves too thin? You never have relatives who seem to fight with everybody?

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: Right. There is always that one person that just wants to go at everybody.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.sentences: Yes, but if they have a valid point, in fact, if the facts back up what he says about...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: He has as lot of legitimate...

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: I have looked into these numbers. He has a lot of legitimate beefs with these guys. But we are also dealing with China. We are also dealing with Korea. You got to pick and choose.

utterances.speaker: GABRIELLE
utterances.sentences: Well, people are worried that we are isolating ourselves from our friends. But I will say this. So many of our relationships with our allies come down to our defense with them and the relationships that were forged through common defense. And I will tell you, our allies, they are going to be there for us when they need us. They are going to be our friends when they need us. And...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: You are very young to be so jaded, yes, but you're probably right.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.sentences: Historically, too.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.sentences: I'm sure not everyone has seen eye to eye historically. And maybe, in keeping up appearances, they do in front of the cameras, and then behind the scenes...

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: There's nothing anyone can do to change this, clearly. He is going to keep tweeting, whether you like it or not.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But let me -- I would be remiss if I didn't mention this, because he's also fighting over the people who come to the White House or don't come to the White House. The NBA championship, of course, isn't over. This is the basketball one?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Anyway, the president has already had this to say about a potential White House visit from the winning team. Take a listen.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I didn't invite LeBron James. And I didn't invite Steph Curry. We are not going to invite either team. But we have other teams that are coming. My attitude, if they want to be here, it's the greatest place on Earth. I'm here. If they don't want to be here, I don't want them.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: What do you think of that?

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, I agreed with Trump, the president, on a lot of things, but here I'm kind of -- I don't think the whole team should be penalized just because -- or punished just because of a couple players. Like, last year, when the Astros won, you had Beltran and Correa, they both didn't go to the White House to be honored, but the rest of the team went. So, just because have you an outspoken LeBron and Steph Curry doesn't -- or Steve Kerr as well -- I don't think that should hurt the other players from being honored. It's a privilege. Just because you don't agree with the president doesn't mean that you don't respect the office of the president.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: So, whose fault is it?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.sentences: I think it's guilty by association. You have the most outspoken people on the team saying these things, and Trump is going to take it to heart. And then he's going to then say, well, you know what? No one is coming then. You have ruined it for everybody. Everybody, out of the pool.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: He probably just didn't want to deal with it. He kind of -- I'm grateful that we have avoided the whole -- a whole news cycle of people saying, oh, I'm not going to go to the White House.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, don't worry. You're not invited. What do you make of that?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly. He said, well, you are not invited. Just I know it's a traditional thing, but just like he doesn't go to the White House Correspondents Dinner, he's just trying to nip things in the bud and keep from having to deal with these issues.

utterances.speaker: GABRIELLE
utterances.sentences: I think that's true. And I think that, if any of these players were like, oh, I really, really want to go to the White House, I think he would be like, come on. Come have dinner at the White House.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GABRIELLE
utterances.sentences: But who wants to have somebody over to their house for dinner if they don't want to be there?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Like, if you knew Gunz was coming, wouldn't you by definition not...

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: I'm a whole lot of fun, I swear.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.sentences: He is nipping it in the bud. He's like, you know what?

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: You know what? I don't know want to even go.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.sentences: I'm not even going to put the spread out.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: This reminds me of life on Mars. See the segue there?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Great transition.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: You're good at this.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Anyway, apparently they have been investigating. And this rover, this has been traversing the lunar -- I'm sorry -- the Martian surface now for the better part of five, six years. Anyway, they seem to have indicated, NASA, that it's discovered the elements that have been there for life billions of years ago. It's a big deal. We're sending up another capsule that is going to actually burrow inside the planet. We always look for life up there. And now there are indications, at least at a time, it might have had it.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.sentences: I think this is great. I think hopefully will kick-start the whole NASA whole program again and get us back at the forefront, because with the last administration kind of relegating NASA to like solve what was happening with like car crash problems...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But we don't give up with Mars, do we? Mars is the place.

utterances.speaker: GABRIELLE
utterances.sentences: No, we got to keep going. And, in fact, I called my good buddy Buzz Aldrin on this one, because he is the self-proclaimed...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: The second man to walk on the moon.

utterances.speaker: GABRIELLE
utterances.sentences: But I did call him. And he said, look, when you -- he said, we have got to explore. If we don't explore, we expire. And he is really passionate about getting a manned mission to Mars and getting people back in space, and also about the U.S. taking leadership again.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But life, about life, the search for life.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: It's not just NASA either. We have all these billionaires. It's like, as soon as you become a rich dude, all you want to do is go to space. I don't understand that at all.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: It's their money.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: I just want to send Nancy Pelosi there. Get her out.

utterances.speaker: GUNZELMAN
utterances.sentences: She looks like an alien anyway.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Everything comes back.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.sentences: But you think of other -- OK. That means for me to be quiet.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Well, that finished thought on "Cavuto Live" tomorrow at 10:00 a.m. He comes back to finish it. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC.
